answers.author: Pooja Varma
answers.text:
Hi Susan, 
I was able to locate some examples of standing committee procedures that should be useful. 
City Council Standing Committee Procedure from the City of Spokane which discusses the requisites for appointing members, meeting schedules, and minutes.  http://bit.ly/mSc29G 
Rules and Procedure: City Council of Richmond VA provides the standing committee composition reasoning, meetings and limitations and explains how its recommendations fit into general meeting agenda.   http://www.richmondgov.com/CityClerk/documents/RulesofProcedure.pdf 
There are a few documents on the KN that relate more generally to council- staff relations.  
Council –Staff Communication Guidelines from the City of Shoreline- describes the duties of the council and staff and how the two relate and support each other in their functions.  
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/3884/CouncilStaff_Communication_Guidelines 
Preparing Councils for Their Work- states examples of how City Managers should manage communication and transparency with council members such as meeting each individually at least once every quarter.  
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/5169/Preparing_Councils_for_Their_Work 
City Council Protocol of Pal Alto - outlines acceptable conduct between council members and city staff. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/5061/City_Council_Protocols 
Perhaps some other Knowledge Network users can give you specific examples from their staff procedures? 
Pooja Varma 
International City/County Management Association 
Knowledge Network Intern 
pvarma@icma.org

author: Susan Thorpe
text: Our City Council is potentially interested in creating several standing council committees (with three members each) to address various operational categories - such as finance and budget, public safety, etc. I'm interested in your suggestions about the City STAFF  side of this issue - (1) what role do the CM and the ACM play, (2) what positions are assigned to staff each committee, who is assigned to create agendas, post notices, take notes etc. (3) what is the time commitment of staff related to each committee, assuming they meet monthly, (4) how does this change the formal council meetings, if at all?  I appreciate any advice you have based on your experiences. - Susan Thorpe, Deputy City Manager, Peoria AZ
title: Staff Work Process for Council Committees
